docs.lead_paragraph: This 30-second advertisement for Senator John Kerry will run on the Black Entertainment Television cable network and in 27 cities through the Democratic National Convention at month's end. It is part of a $2 million blitz intended for African-Americans that also includes several radio and newspaper advertisements. PRODUCER: UniWorld Group Inc. ON THE SCREEN: The spot opens with Mr. Kerry, in open-collar shirt, speaking directly to the camera. Video of Mr. Kerry talking in small groups, all with African-Americans prominently visible, alternates with gray screens captioned with the crux of the message. A black woman and a white woman nod as if in response to the narrator's question, ''Does he care about me?'' There is a close-up of black children, and an image of Mr. Kerry hugging a black man.

headline.main: A Kerry Appeal to Black Voters

docs.abstract: Appraisal of 30-second advertisement for Sen John Kerry that will run on Black Entertainment Television cable network and in 27 cities through Democratic National Convention; it is part of $2 million blitz intended for African-Americans that also includes radio and newspaper advertisments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A small change in the language of a government manual has opened the door for obesity treatments to be covered under Medicare, the Bush administration said on Thursday. A new policy handed down by the Department of Health and Human Services removes the phrase ''obesity itself cannot be considered an illness'' from the Medicare Coverage Issues Manual, allowing scientists, clinicians and companies to submit proposals recommending that certain treatments be covered. The change was first reported on Thursday in The Wall Street Journal.

headline.main: A Deletion Opens Medicare To Coverage for Obesity

docs.abstract: Small change in language of government manual opens door for obesity treatments to be covered by Medicare; American Obesity Assn says 18 percent of Medicare population is obese (M)

byline.original: By MARK GLASSMAN; Robert Pear contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: If past patterns are any guide, about one in three Americans will go without health insurance for some part of the next two years. They won't, for the most part, be the persistently poor, who are usually covered by Medicaid. They will be members of working families with breadwinners who have jobs without medical benefits or who have been laid off. Many Americans fear the loss of health insurance. Last week I described John Kerry's health plan. What's the Bush administration's plan?
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column compares and contrasts health plans put forward by Pres Bush and Sen John Kerry; says Bush's proposed tax credit would reduce number of uninsured by 1.8 million out of total of 44 million, and his tax-free health savings accounts would be boon for wealthier people; says Kerry offers plan that would extend coverage of health insurance to most of those now uninsured, paid for by rolling back tax cuts for those with incomes over $200,000; says he cannot see how Bush could win this debate (M)
docs.snippet: If past patterns are any guide, about one in three Americans will go without health insurance for some part of the next two years. They won't, for the most part, be the persistently poor, who are usually covered by Medicaid. They will be members of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Jurors acquitted eight current and former employees of TAP Pharmaceutical Products on Wednesday of charges they offered doctors improper consulting fees, dinners, golf trips and other incentives to induce them to prescribe certain drugs. The federal jury deliberated for parts of four days after a three-month trial.

headline.main: Eight Acquitted in Drug Incentives Case

docs.abstract: Jurors acquitted eight current and former employees of TAP Pharmaceutical Products on charges they offered doctors incentives to induce them to prescribe certain drugs; government also charged that current and former executives and sales managers at TAP conspired to defraud Medicare and Medicaid by urging doctors to bill government for free drug samples (M)
docs.snippet: Jurors acquitted eight current and former employees of TAP Pharmaceutical Products on Wednesday of charges they offered doctors improper consulting fees, dinners, golf trips and other incentives to induce them to prescribe certain drugs.      The...

docs.lead_paragraph: MEDCO Health Solutions began its first big advertising campaign yesterday, with ads created not just to promote the company brand but also to demystify what Medco, a pharmacy benefit manager, does. Pharmacy benefit managers, often called P.B.M.'s, administer drug benefits for clients like insurance companies and employers. The largest companies in the category include Medco, Caremark and Express Scripts. ''To the best of our knowledge, this will be the largest effort by a P.B.M. to both sell the category and put Medco on the map,'' said Jack A. Smith, chief marketing officer at Medco in Franklin Lakes, N.J. The company, known as Merck-Medco before it was spun off from Merck & Company last August, found through research that even executives who make decisions about company health plans know little about the pharmacy benefit manager business.

headline.main: Medco hopes ads not only tell clients what it does, but who it is.

docs.abstract: Medco Health Solutions begins first big advertising campaign, with ads created not just to promote company brand but also to demystify what Medco, pharmacy benefit manager, does; campaign was developed by Gotham ad agency; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: At a news conference on Monday, the Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, trumpeted a novel project to spend $1.5 million in restitution from a corruption case to ''root out and prevent waste, fraud and abuse.'' But on Wednesday, embarrassed county officials here suddenly yanked a contract from one of three accounting firms hired to do the work after discovering that its associate had been convicted in the same scandal that prompted the restitution.

headline.main: Nassau Cancels Contract Of Fraud Oversight Firm

docs.abstract: Nassau County Exec Thomas R Suozzi cancels newly awarded contract for accounting firm of Albrecht, Viggiano, Zureck & Co to do corruption prevention work for county after Republicans complain that Robert F Friemann, former partner at firm, was convicted in April of being involved in same transaction that brought home need for greater oversight: switching of health insurance of county workers to Benefits Plan Administrators Co; Friemann, who is awaiting sentencing, still has business relationship with Albrecht that firm did not fully disclose (M)
docs.snippet: At a news conference on Monday, the Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, trumpeted a novel project to spend $1.5 million in restitution from a corruption case to ''root out and prevent waste, fraud and abuse.''    But on Wednesday, embarrassed...

docs.lead_paragraph: United Airlines said yesterday that it would put off making $72.4 million in payments to its employee pension funds, a move that experts said signaled that the airline was likely to seek deep cuts in one or more of its retirement plans. The action, disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, was the first significant step taken by the bankrupt airline since its application for federal loan guarantees was rejected at the end of June.
docs.abstract: United Airlines will put off making $72.4 million in payments to its employee pension funds, move that experts say signals airline is likely to seek deep cuts in one or more of its retirement plans; leaders of some of company's unions react with dismay to deferral (M)
